importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The year the sexual assault occurred at Gettysburg College, marking the beginning of a long period without prosecution.
The year Ian Cleary sent the Facebook message to Shannon Keeler, which reignited her efforts to pursue legal action.
The year Shannon Keeler shared her experience in an Associated Press article, highlighting systemic reluctance to prosecute campus sexual assault cases.
The date Cleary was detained in Metz, France, on a vagrancy charge, which led to his eventual extradition to the U.S. for prosecution.
The date of the sentencing in the case, marking a long-overdue judicial resolution after more than a decade of delay.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The 12-year span between the assault and the final prosecution illustrates the systemic failure and long-term trauma experienced by survivors of campus sexual assault.
The period during which the Facebook message was sent and the victim reactivated her case reflects the role of public awareness in breaking down institutional inaction.

keyTakeAways: Systemic failures in campus sexual assault prosecution, including delayed or dropped cases and loss of forensic evidence, have led to prolonged suffering for survivors.
The case highlights how survivors' persistent efforts and public advocacy can eventually lead to justice, even after years of inaction.
Mental health and criminal behavior are complex factors, and the defendant’s admission of guilt and remorse are considered in sentencing.
Extradition of a fugitive from Europe underscores the challenges in tracking individuals across jurisdictions when they evade law enforcement.
Victims of sexual assault face emotional and psychological trauma that persists long after the incident, and justice is not always swift or accessible.

namedEntities.name: Shannon Keeler
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The victim of the sexual assault at Gettysburg College in 2013 and the central figure in the pursuit of justice.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is the survivor whose long-standing efforts to pursue charges, including public advocacy, led to the eventual prosecution and sentencing of the perpetrator.

namedEntities.name: Ian Cleary
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The man who sexually assaulted Shannon Keeler in 2013 and later sent a Facebook message saying 'So I raped you'.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is the defendant who faced prosecution after being extradited from France, and his actions and mental health history are central to the case's legal and emotional dimensions.

namedEntities.name: Gettysburg College
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The college in Pennsylvania where the sexual assault occurred in 2013.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The location of the crime and the campus environment where the assault and subsequent legal proceedings are rooted.

namedEntities.name: Senior Judge Kevin Hess
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The judge who sentenced Ian Cleary to two to four years in prison.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He delivered the final judicial decision, acknowledging both the gravity of the crime and the defendant's remorse and mental health challenges.

namedEntities.name: Andrea Levy
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Shannon Keeler’s lawyer who represented her in court.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She provided legal advocacy and expressed concerns about the severity of the sentence, reflecting on the broader implications for victims.

namedEntities.name: John Abom
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Cleary’s defense lawyer who argued that Cleary was homeless and unaware of the charges.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He presented a defense based on mental instability and homelessness, which influenced the court’s consideration of the defendant’s circumstances.

namedEntities.name: Brian Sinnett
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The Adams County District Attorney who expressed doubt about Cleary’s awareness of the charges.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His statements reflect the legal challenges in proving the defendant’s knowledge and intent during the investigation and prosecution.

namedEntities.name: Metz, France
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The city in France where Ian Cleary was detained on a vagrancy charge.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It was the location of Cleary’s detention that ultimately enabled his extradition to the U.S. for prosecution.

namedEntities.name: Tesla
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The company where Ian Cleary worked after completing his education.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It reflects Cleary’s post-assault professional trajectory and integration into the tech industry before his legal troubles.

namedEntities.name: Associated Press
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The news outlet that published Shannon Keeler’s story in 2021.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The publication of Keeler’s story prompted renewed attention and led to the indictment of Cleary weeks later.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A man, Ian Cleary, was sentenced to two to four years in prison for sexually assaulting a woman, Shannon Keeler, at Gettysburg College in 2013. The case, which had been dormant for over a decade, was revived when Cleary sent a Facebook message saying 'So I raped you' in 2019, prompting Keeler to re-engage with law enforcement. After being extradited from France in 2024, Cleary pleaded guilty and expressed remorse, citing a 12-step program for mental health. Judge Kevin Hess considered Cleary’s mental illness and remorse in issuing a sentence below state guidelines. Keeler’s long fight to see justice delivered — including a powerful courtroom statement about systemic failures in prosecuting campus sexual assault — highlighted the trauma survivors endure and the failure of institutions to act in time.
title: Man Sentenced to Prison After Facebook Message of 'So I Raped You' to Campus Assault Victim
